Flu surveillance graph

10 Oct 2022 by Josh

Skip table of contents

Table of Contents

  • England - flu fell dramatically

England - flu fell dramatically

From the flu and COVID-19 surveillance reports (licensed under Open Government License v3) this, from page 39 of 2022 week 27 report is Figure 30. ILI is “influenza like illness”

Scepticism about COVID is not really rooted in a lack of information - I think either sentiment, misinformation and self interest are stronger drivers. But in case more information help the graph on the following page, Figure 31, was also quite striking and showing that COVID-19 consultation rates far exceeding historical flu consultation rates - a point in rebuttal to any “old diseases, new labels” thinking. The key points to me in the graph are the much higher consulation rates for COVID-19 - and the later peaks outside of influenza season.

Cross-referencing with the ONS coronavirus infection survey for week ending 26th of March 2022 that had about 1 in 13 people having COVID-19 during that week - which was in week 13 around the time of the peak of 600 per 100k seen in Figure 31’s COVID-19 indicator.

Indicator caveats

One needs to bear in mind with all these indicators that consultations depending on getting through to a GP (and same day GP appointments unless urgent is unlikely where I am). But with that in mind the much lower consulation rate might indicate more asymptomatic or less severe cases. The lower mortality rates, seen here, among the unvaccinated for Omicron definitely indicates it is hitting the survivors less hard than previous variants.

Flu is falling

But beyond caveats about the indicators I have on the pandemic scientific papers page herea couple of papers showing pretty clearly that flu is having a harder time spreading - so much so that [a lineage has quite possibly gone extinct]https://www.nature.com/articles/s41579-021-00642-4) - likely due to a combination of coronavirus infection control measures and the lack of an animal reservior for that lineage (basically animals who will get the flu and not practice social distancing - as hey they are animals).
